review_title: Excellent, caring company to work for

pros: Location of Hammersmith office on riverfront with WFH flexibility. Good managerial/director salaries. Inclusive recruitment. A genuine promotion of workplace wellbeing and some great individuals.
cons: Minimal Leadership accountability. Junior staff overworked and very underpaid for their role, especially Coordinator roles in Operations, Customer Services and Qualifications. There is high turnover in the company, particularly in these departments. Workplace wellbeing strategies are often sidelined by workload and have limited continued leadership to actually make these effective. The messaging is positive and there is a genuine care about people's health and wellbeing, but the actual impact is limited as the core workplace issues are never addressed. There is a feeling of a lack of company strategy and direction. There are often 10+ strategic aims set by the senior management which are often too broad to be effective. There are some talented workers and managers who are held back by the overwhelming lack of change. No serious career progression can be offered due to the company structure. Limited departmental collaboration on large projects with junior staffers often taking on most of the decision making. If there are head count reductions, senior managers and directors will never be at risk of redundancy.

Training opportunities available and the team are very friendly and always deliver. With coronavirus forcing us to work from home, they have shown their agility by moving their products and client meetings online, and are showing real ambition to grow as a young charity.

pros:
Beautiful location by the river thames
Nice people (entry level staff)
cons:
Staff are very overworked and underpaid with the excuse of the company being a "charity". How they are now trying to promote wellbeing when they do not care about the wellbeing of their own staff, is beyond me.

Senior management DO NOT like change , so if you come there looking to implement any ideas or suggest new ways of working - they'll have you out of there in no time.

The company has had the same people working there for ages, some directors have been responsible for all departments! It's the same people (pr person should I say)pulling the strings at the top and has had many contracts terminated just because they've found something not to like about you.

Same people getting "promoted" all the time - the company creates roles for people who they like.

HR is a puppet for the directors and will be no use if you have any issues.

Not enough diversity 

Managers are getting paid for nothing and very complacent- they have no clue on how to manage and will try and keep you down especially if
you're someone with your own mind.

Company operates as a startup even though they've been operating for over 60 years, just so far behind with everything.

No room for progression at all - you'd literally just side step into different departments without gaining any additional skills.

It is a huge waste of time being employed there. All they'll give you is a marketable job title without actually giving you the skills and knowledge to perform that role anywhere else. 

If you are a first/second jobber or someone coming from retail, customer service etc then it's somewhere to start as you'd learn how to compose emails, answer calls etc but believe it would not be a true reflection of office jobs in the real world as opposed to "BSC's world".

Take what you can, as quickly as you can and leave - please do not hinder the rest of your career by staying there or believing that they have some to offer you somewhere down the line.

job_title: Director of Finance in Hammersmith, England
pros:
Aside from:
1) Free cooked breakfast
2) Free fruit
3) Very decent working hours for London (official hours 9am - 5pm)
4) Flexible working hours
5) A very inclusive, multicultural workforce

British Safety Council is a great place to work as the CEO and Executive Directors are very receptive to new starters with new ideas, wanting to improve processes and keen to make a difference in a business that is going through change. 

 I am fortunate enough to have been promoted within 3 months of joining. I love working at British Safety Council as I can see the things that need to be fixed and I am empowered to make the changes. It's great to work somewhere where effort is rewarded and where the management structure supports and is receptive to change.
cons: The business is evolving so staff and new starters need to be receptive to change. If you want to work somewhere where every day is the same British Safety Council probably isn't for you.

review_title: Good company. You get back what you put in.
pros: There is a staff dining area where cooked breakfasts and dinner are served. There are flexible working hours, bit normal hours are 9-5 so this works well. You feel like your suggestions are heard, and feel like you can make a difference. There are social events that help all departments come together. It is also a multicultural place to work, with a good group of friendly staff. There is also opportunity for progression as the company evolves and expands. Salary is good with a decent commission structure, but with any sales job you get what you put in. Management try to support you in the best way they can.
cons: Frustrating at time with poor communication, and slow to react to needs. Management sometimes absent when needed.

job_title: Key Account Manager in Hammersmith, England
pros: British Safety Council is a charity with a vision nobody should be injured or hurt by their work.  I love the fact that everything I contribute to in this organisation, and Mates in Mind is to support this. We are always striving to be the best and the leader is everything we do, ensuring it's the best experience  possible for every client and every delegate. I feel passionate about working for both charities and proud that I am a part of the journey.
cons: Sometimes we try and do too much and don't always join everything together. Some of the internal processes offer challenges and delays which can be frustrating, but I know the SLT are working on trying to change this.

job_title: Membership Sales Team Leader in Hammersmith, England
pros: Small company feel but big company vision. It's a small charity but if you put the effort in you will be rewarded. I moved up in under nine months to lead a sales team and I enjoyed my time there a lot.  Training is ok but you do have to fight for it. The staff are amazing and friendly and willing to help you out. The company helped me through some rough personal patches and when they found out I  as leaving for a dream job were extremely supportive of sad to see me go.
cons: The pay could certainly be improved and the board of trustees need to appreciate the staff more.
